body:
@eppleton the referenced article argues, to _not_ ask the user at all, if the developer should know better and the user can be expected not to care/know. We can't take that road, as there are different pros and cons to choose the build system and the option needs to be there. So the user needs to choose and needs information to base its decision on. Given that the difference between the two options is the build system I don't see why that fact should be hidden and why that would help the developer at all.

Before the the change there was:
- Java: An ant based project with netbeans specific project files
- Maven: A maven based project without any netbeans specifics

No we have:
- Java
- Ant Java

So what tells me what "Java" does? If my peer group says "gradle" is _the_ build system, I would expect that to be created. Bummer - does not happen - there is some file "pom.xml" generated, but no  "build.gradle". You can replace "gradle" with $featured build system. So why not:

- Java (maven based)
- Java (ant based)

Putting maven first, indicates to order "we" suggest and lets the user choose.
@eppleton Oh, of course we all want the best for the user. Apologies for my bad explanation. I like best your proposal of explaining the build system "Java (ant based)" and "Java (maven based)".
Tested. Works. The code seems reasonable.
@emilianbold please review.
Also see twin [PR-1047](https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/1047) for  NetBeans 10.0
It seems that there are conflicts.
@jlahoda please review. This is the only big blocker before vc5
Tried it, works for me on Mac OS, awesome.
Seems sensible to me.
all> thanks for the reviews/testing.

Hi I ask @sdedic for review as it's more or less the same than for release100 branch.

Would be nice to merge if ok.

Is there a little documentation how to use it? I mean what do I need to do to expect syntax highlighting for new langauges? Putting tmLanguage files into a dir and everything works? That would be a dream come true :).

The current steps are roughly:
-(in a NetBeans module), create a new file type:
New/Other/Module Development/File Type
pick a mime type, presumably "text/<second-part>".
-then add an XML Layer:
New/Other/Module Development/XML Layer
next to the XML layer, copy the TextMate grammar and edit the layer like this:
```
<filesystem>
    <folder name="Editors">
        <folder name="text">
            <folder name="<second-part>">
                <file name="<grammar-name>" url="<grammar-name>">
                    <attr name="textmate-grammar" stringvalue="<scopeName-from-the-grammar>" />
                </file>
            </folder>
        </folder>
    </folder>
</filesystem>
```
Filling: <second-part> from text/<second-part>, <grammar-name> with the filename of the grammar and <scopeName-from-the-grammar> with the value of the "scopeName" from the top-level of the grammar.
-run the module (F6) - with a little luck, the IDE could syntax-highlight files with the given extensions using the grammar.

I'd be intrigued to hear any experiences with this. There are some opportunities for simplification (instead of manually creating a layer, there could be an annotation on the DataObject which would generate the layer automatically, and then this could be (an optional) part of the wizard).
@jlahoda would like to test it. Where did you find the VS Code examples? From the repos of the plugins?

What I can think of is only having a folder for supported languages with sub folders for the specific languages.

textmate-languages (folder) -> rust (folder) (e.g.)

So in this we should have a JSON or more the Java/NetBeans way, a XML file like with the part from the layer.xml or from a resolver.xml file.

So I want to add the mimetype like "text/rust", the filetype ".rs" the icon, references to other files like the language specification file, a file for braces matchings and a file for snippets. That would be an easy way. 

So if you open NetBeans or an option like "load supported languages", NetBeans should create the needed stuff for a new language automatically. So if you open now a Rust file, it should have the new mimetype, the new icon, basic syntax highlighting, braces matching (if I added it) and snippets (if I added it). Thats it. Sounds easy and I don't know whether this is possible or not. But for someone who wants to add a new language with basic functionality, I don't want to write Java classes etc. create a new project bla bla bla. This should still be possible for more advanced features.

My 2 cents.

As for examples, this one may work (I *think* I was trying with this one):
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/rust/syntaxes/rust.tmLanguage.json

As for the "I don't want to write Java classes", well, I can understand that. But this change was never intended to do so. It only adds support for reading TextMate grammar and syntax highlight based on that. But recognizing mime types is not part of this. After all, even for VS Code, if one wants to use LSP, one needs to write some code.

Frankly, I don't think I have immediate plans to work on replacing the DataObjects written in Java with something else, sorry. I'd be happy if someone implemented your suggestions (you?), I have nothing against that. But, w.r.t. this PR, I guess the main question is when you start to implement your suggestions, the code in this PR going to a) help you; b) have neither positive nor negative effect on your work; c) be harmful to your work. If you think it is c), then I guess we should wait for your PR, and I am fine with that.

For the DataObject, I never said that we should replace it. If it sounds so, then sry. Writing Java for more advanced stuff or what we still have is totally fine. Now we have JavaCC (Which is deprecated), ANTLR, JFLex I think too(?) and now textMate based grammar, which is pretty cool. Thx for your great work.

I only want to say that there should be an more easy option to implement SIMPLE language support w/o writing Java. So my which where to copy and paste the files/folders from the VS Code Repo / extensions to our own folder with some rewriting, etc. and it should work out of the box. That is easy. If you still want to create more language features it is possible and should be possible to write it further with Java, nothing wrong with that. For advanced features you need advanced writings.

I thought so to do some implementation, now with the textMate grammar it could be possible for a PoC. So again tthx for your work. Atm I have some other priorities.

TextMate will still help us I think because they have some more modern languages like Go, D (?), Rust C# etc. So it was worth it to implement it :)
@phansson can you be so kind pleaes and fix what @emilianbold requested? Otherwise we should close it, maybe.
I was mostly commenting on top of it back then. Nothing from what I've said was a hard -1 so to speak. Please carry on.

Hi @emilianbold, would just notify that I want to merge on release90 to have apidoc prepared for generation. (as you are the release manager for release90)

Best Regards

I have nothing against this PR, seems to only do some minor changes. We don't need to do another 9.0 release so all is well.

+1
merging apidoc branding
Should probably be part of release100 branch too?

I think the correct URL is: http://plugins.netbeans.org/nbpluginportal/updates/8.2/catalog.xml.gz
This is the URL in Netbeans 8.2 for its Plugin Portal.

The URL http://updates.netbeans.org/netbeans/updates/8.2/uc/final/certified/catalog.xml.gz (in this PR) gives me around 20 plugins.
The URL http://plugins.netbeans.org/nbpluginportal/updates/8.2/catalog.xml.gz gives me around 170 plugins.

NetBeans 8.2 has 2 entries: the certified portal and the (free for all) plugin portal.

I believe Apache should suggest the 'certified' plugins, which underwent some vetting.
Closing, does not seem to be quite relevant right now. We can redo this, if needed.

In the light of:
http://mail.openjdk.java.net/pipermail/jdk-dev/2018-December/002401.html

We may not want to do this at this time.
Superseded by other PRs.

Today I got the permission to use the npm logo:

> Hi, Chris!  Sorry for the delay.  I wanted to loop our trademark and copyright counsel in on this, just to make sure I wasn't doing something dumb :)

>The Apache Netbeans IDE has asked for permission to use the npm logo to represent the filetype of files named "package.json" and "package-lock.json" in the IDE. Thanks for asking, and yes, you have our permission to do so. You also linked the logo at https://github.com/vscode-icons/vscode-icons/blob/master/icons/file_type_npm.svg, which is the icon that you may use.
Thanks for your patience and for reaching out to us about this matter.  Looking forward to seeing the npm logo in Netbeans :)

>Cheers!

So pleaes have a look and leave comments.

Summerize:
* Created a new DataObject for "package.json" called PackageJsonDataObject to add a new file icon.
* Removed old layer.xml file
* Moved annotation for MimeResolver from PackageJson.java to PackageJsonDataObject.java
* Added the npm icon to the code. I got the permission to use it.

Let me know, if anything is still unclear.

Here you can see the result:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/795658/50287309-93884c00-0462-11e9-98cb-717d8ff165d5.png)
I am not very familiar with JavaScript package managers, but isn't package.json also used by other package managers such as Yarn?

Yes, and for pnpm too, but initially it came from npm. yarn also uses node_modules, pnpm too. So from the core they are pretty much the same. The difference is how they treat the modules. Hard linking, caching, etc. So in general if someone will see the npm logo or package.json, if they google for it, they will figure it out quickly. https://www.google.com/search?q=package.json

The diff looks much more difficult, than the change really is. The check for the license reference (original file lines 232-234) was to broad and potentially also filtered notices. The generation of the notice entry was moved out of the conditional and is always executed, the license check was enhanced to accept plain ALv2 and the variant with copyright assignment to the ASF.

I just build netbeans master (clean source tree, just running `ant` so building the default cluster) and noticed, that the LICENSE file now lists GPL-2-CP files:

```
matthias@athena:~/src/incubator-netbeans$ cat nbbuild/netbeans/LICENSE | grep GPL-2-CP                                                                                                              
extra/modules/ext/javafx-base-11-linux.jar                            GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-base-11-mac.jar                              GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-base-11-win.jar                              GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-controls-11-linux.jar                        GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-controls-11-mac.jar                          GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-controls-11-win.jar                          GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-graphics-11-linux.jar                        GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-graphics-11-mac.jar                          GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-graphics-11-win.jar                          GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-media-11-linux.jar                           GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-media-11-mac.jar                             GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-media-11-win.jar                             GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-swing-11-linux.jar                           GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-swing-11-mac.jar                             GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-swing-11-win.jar                             GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-web-11-linux.jar                             GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-web-11-mac.jar                               GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
extra/modules/ext/javafx-web-11-win.jar                               GPL-2-CP                                                                                                                      
matthias@athena:~/src/incubator-netbeans$ 
```

Netbeans 11 is not releasable in that state. Please ensure, that the files are not part of the distribution. GPL-2-CP is still not cleared by the ASF and thus we can't redistribute GPL-2-CP files
Great, thanks a lot, merging.

Not really. One thing I do note is that the workaround implemented in this PR doesn't work sometimes (I have it integrated into a company product). I might check on this later when I want to update the relevant code.
The `@Test` tests nothing, but at least it doesn't fail. Any other fix is welcomed, @eirikbakke.

AutoHidingMenuBarManualTest is _not_ intended to run automatically at build time. It's merely kept around as a convenience for any developer who wishes to make changes to AutoHidingMenuBar, and who needs a quick way to test the behavior manually without running the entire IDE.

Where does the "No runnable methods" error come from? What are the conditions that make it trigger? What parameters should I have passed to ant during my own build in order for this error to surface on my local machine?

Would renaming AutoHidingMenuBarManualTest to something that doesn't end in "Test" fix the error?
Can you provide instructions for creating an installer without including a JDK, is that possible with this PR?
I think this will require some changes. It didn't work out of the box by just setting env property BUILD_NBJDK11=0. I will be able to investigate after I'm back next week.

OK, I managed to trigger the error with "ant -Dtest-unit-sys-prop.ignore.random.failures=true test" run from the core.windows package only. Sorry I didn't catch this before! I was trying to run tests from the root NetBeans repo before, but got a lot of unrelated errors on even on a clean checkout, so I didn't have an effective way to pick out the error caused specifically by my own patch.

Renaming "AutoHidingMenuBarManualTest" to "AutoHidingMenuBarManualTestApp" fixes the error.

On a side note, it would be lovely if we could make GitHub pull requests show errors when there are problems like these. At the moment it says "All checks have passed" as long as a test-less build passes, giving a false impression that PRs can be merged without breaking the build:

![allcheckspassed](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/886243/50539535-28392b00-0b82-11e9-808c-8fafbae91947.png)
Thank you both for checking. Merging.
That would be excellent, thanks.

I have two formal replies:

Well, this patch is based on [Ivan Friedlnder comments on NETBEANS-168](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-168?focusedCommentId=16729581&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-16729581).

Submitted an issue to them: https://github.com/NBANDROIDTEAM/org-netbeans-modules-masterfs-patches/issues/1 and I hope they could contribute those back, then our sages can review and hopefully integrate back to the master. This PR would be useless then.

From a technical perspective I think this is good to go. I ran the build and found, that the new icon is present in the package.json file, the file still has syntax highlighting and the node actions are also correctly present.

We need to be careful with the artwork though. We already need to discuss enough about licenses. For external files we record the information in a file named licenseinfo.xml - see details here:
https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/NETBEANS/Legal+FAQ#LegalFAQ-licenseinfoPerfileinfo-licenseinfo.xml
There are several samples in the codebase for the file. Having the file ensures, that the license for the graphics is correctly included in the summary and if needed attributions are included in the NOTICE file.

The author of the masterfs module did not know that the file.exists() returns false for a broken link.
There is FileChangedManager and that's the biggest problem, there is a cached condition of file existence. `FileChangedManager.exists() and FileChangedManager.impeachExistence()`

The code is terribly complex and the analysis is for a few days. 
And I feel that direct reading of the file states takes less cpu time as the monster..

And the biggest problem is my Google translator English..
Well, I do not really mind if you discuss this issue with @JaroslavTulach and or @jlahoda in your native language as long as we got a summary in English at the end. So go ahead!

I've prepared the proposed change at https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/1067 ; closing this PR as suggested.
The Travis build succeeded, and the patch fixes the test locally on my machine, so I will now merge this and verify that the test no longer fails after Jenkins does its job.

I have no idea how to edit the so called "wiki". Wikis usually come with an edit button. I cannot find any at http://netbeans.apache.org/wiki/ Searching for "edit" text doesn't find anything useful either. Anyway, that is not a complain to be solved in this PR.

Yes, the API check is part of the travis build. See [line 27](https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/blob/9f107db49347616b9ce4885ffc11032023cb276d/.travis.yml#L27). E.g. the build is supposed to fail when anyone makes an incompatible API change.

The aa8466e83e17a5c96ec8e7d6343100c7ffe90f66 change makes this check part of single module build - when you press `F11` in a module with some API - e.g. `platform/openide.util.lookup` and there is an incompatible change then the build fails.

Good question. What's the license of AdoptOpenJDK? Well, here you can see it is based on OpenJDK, which is GPL, so no, it cannot be distributed from Apache in a bundle with NetBeans (though, I believe, it could bundle NetBeans with itself and distribute it): https://adoptopenjdk.net/about.html

I've created new [jenkins job](https://builds.apache.org/job/incubator-netbeans-linux-jdk11/) to test platform on JDK11. Once this PR is integrated, the job should compile and run the tests (with some failures).

FWIW, there is also "test.nbjdk.home" which is a JDK on which the tests are run (while the compilation still uses nbjdk.home).

I found the best place to patch the file event system.

Why isn't `test.nbjdk.home` derived from value of `nbjdk.home`?

Feel free to make test.nbjdk.home fallback to to nbjdk.home, although I am not quite sure if there's a point. The launcher used to run the tests will either be derived from test.nbjdk.home (if present and usable) or from nbjdk.home (otherwise). I.e. using test.nbjdk.home is optional, but allows to compile and run tests on different JDKs.
The problem is that without specifying test.nbjdk.home the tests fallback to JAVA_HOME and not to nbjdk.home. I found that confusing.
The job run [#10](https://builds.apache.org/job/incubator-netbeans-linux-jdk11/10) finished with 110 failed tests. Anyone who cares about JDK11 and NetBeans Platform is welcomed to fix some!

Can I get some approvals, please? Although these checks were already in for the NetBeans Platform and nobody found a problem, The extension of the API compatibility checks to all modules with an API deserves some agreement.

Re.  Emilian's "make sure we don't expose more than expected" - actually no. These checks still allow you to add new elements to the API compatibly. These test only prevent us from *removing* APIs accidentally. E.g. They only check [backward binary compatibility](http://wiki.apidesign.org/wiki/Binary_compatibility).
Well, it seems the method how this was done is documented. i see no reason not to integrate this into master. So I approve this change, if that means something.

Not sure why you are seeing that fallback (of specifically test.nbjdk.home, nbjdk.home sometimes falls back to ${java.home}), but please feel free to fix.

The only use of test.nbjdk.home I see in the sources is in nbbuild/jdk.xml:
```
        <condition property="test.nbjdk.java" value="${test.nbjdk.home}/bin/java${.exe}" else="${nbjdk.home}/bin/java${.exe}">
            <and>
                <isset property="test.nbjdk.home" />
                <available file="${test.nbjdk.home}/bin/java${.exe}" type="file"/>
            </and>
        </condition>
```

I.e. the test.nbjdk.java property is used to infer test.nbjdk.java property, and that falls back to nbjdk.home. The uses of test.nbjdk.java are in common.xml, and specify the Java launcher for testing.
Sure, I'll look into it when I have more time.

I am not sure either, but I had to make few corrective commits to the PR to make it really buildable on JDK-11. For some reason the tests were compiled with JDK8 classpath that contains methods and classes removed in JDK-11. E.g. the compilation of tests picked `JAVA_HOME` up somehow.

What shall be the next steps with this PR? Can those who object to currently proposed version (@matthiasblaesing, @vieiro) modify the PR so it is acceptable for them?

Btw. recently I was teaching my kids Java and found a [nice course that uses NetBeans](https://www.itnetwork.cz/java/zaklady/java-tutorial-instalace-a-ovladani-netbeans-ide-konzolova-aplikace)! Having courses like this is an excellent value that we don't want to loose. It has to be admitted that for existing materials like this, it is important to keep the Ant based projects around and _deprecate_ them _carefully_.

Since this is going to impact one of the very first steps in all of our tutorials, and could have an adverse effect on the starting point of each and every newbie of Apache NetBeans, I think we should together take a look at the impact of this on the documentation -- i.e., if someone can't do step 1 because they cannot find the project template described in step 1 of a tutorial, there's a real chance they'll not go to step 2 at all.
